That's a great idea! Entertainment and lifestyle publications like Vanity Fair and Us Weekly can often provide a unique perspective on documentaries and films related to climate change. They may highlight films that are more accessible or appealing to a broader audience, or feature interviews with celebrities who are passionate about environmental causes.

Vanity Fair, in particular, has a strong focus on culture, politics, and social issues, so they may have in-depth features or interviews with filmmakers, activists, or celebrities who are working on climate-related projects. Us Weekly, on the other hand, may focus more on celebrity involvement in environmental causes or highlight films that are more mainstream or popular.

By checking out these publications, you may discover documentaries or films that you wouldn't have otherwise come across. You might also find interviews or features that provide a more personal or human perspective on the issue of climate change, which can be just as powerful as in-depth feature articles or documentaries.

Additionally, you may find that these publications highlight films or documentaries that are more focused on the cultural or social impacts of climate change, rather than just the scientific or environmental aspects. This can provide a more well-rounded understanding of the issue and its effects on different communities and industries.

Remember, every perspective and voice matters in the conversation around climate change, and exploring different types of publications and media can help you gain a more nuanced understanding of the issue.

Enjoy your search, and I hope you discover some new and thought-provoking documentaries or films to share with your friends!
